segment.source: About Application Virtualization Packages
segment.target: About Application Virtualization Packages

segment.source: About Application Virtualization Packages
segment.target: About Application Virtualization Packages

segment.source: About Application Virtualization Packages
segment.target: About Application Virtualization Packages

segment.source: In Application Virtualization, a package is the output of the sequencing process.
segment.target: In Application Virtualization, a package is the output of the sequencing process.

segment.source: You use packages when you first deploy applications on your servers and when you upgrade applications with a new version.
segment.target: You use packages when you first deploy applications on your servers and when you upgrade applications with a new version.

segment.source: Packages enable you to control virtual application versions on your Application Virtualization Management Servers.
segment.target: Packages enable you to control virtual application versions on your Application Virtualization Management Servers.

segment.source: A single package can contain one or more applications.
segment.target: A single package can contain one or more applications.

segment.source: Each application package contains a set of files as a self-contained unit.
segment.target: Each application package contains a set of files as a self-contained unit.

segment.source: Managing Packages
segment.target: Managing Packages

segment.source: After the Sequencer creates a package of one or more applications as part of its process, you can copy the Sequencer-generated files to a Application Virtualization Management Server and make them available for streaming.
segment.target: After the Sequencer creates a package of one or more applications as part of its process, you can copy the Sequencer-generated files to a Application Virtualization Management Server and make them available for streaming.

segment.source: Available packages appear under the Packages container in the left pane of the Application Virtualization Management Console.
segment.target: Available packages appear under the Packages container in the left pane of the Application Virtualization Management Console.

segment.source: When you import an application with a Sequencer Project (SPRJ) file or an Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file, a related entry appears in the Packages container.
segment.target: When you import an application with a Sequencer Project (SPRJ) file or an Open Software Descriptor (OSD) file, a related entry appears in the Packages container.

segment.source: From the Application Virtualization Server Management Console, you can then deploy, upgrade, or delete packages and versions of them.
segment.target: From the Application Virtualization Server Management Console, you can then deploy, upgrade, or delete packages and versions of them.

segment.source: Each virtual application has an associated package.
segment.target: Each virtual application has an associated package.

segment.source: This package includes the following files:
segment.target: This package includes the following files:

segment.source: SFT—The file that streams the application to clients.
segment.target: SFT—The file that streams the application to clients.

segment.source: OSD—The Open Software Descriptor file contains the information needed to find and launch the application.
segment.target: OSD—The Open Software Descriptor file contains the information needed to find and launch the application.

segment.source: ICO—The icon file that visually represents the application in user interfaces and shortcuts.
segment.target: ICO—The icon file that visually represents the application in user interfaces and shortcuts.

segment.source: SPRJ—The Sequencer Project file.
segment.target: SPRJ—The Sequencer Project file.

segment.source: When you import the SPRJ file, all sequenced applications are available for deployment, by default, but the applications are not enabled for streaming.
segment.target: When you import the SPRJ file, all sequenced applications are available for deployment, by default, but the applications are not enabled for streaming.

segment.source: You can choose to stream all or some of the applications in the package.
segment.target: You can choose to stream all or some of the applications in the package.

segment.source: For example, if you sequenced and imported Microsoft Office, you can choose not to deploy some applications, such as the Save My Settings Wizard.
segment.target: For example, if you sequenced and imported Microsoft Office, you can choose not to deploy some applications, such as the Save My Settings Wizard.

segment.source: In this case, right-click each application you want to deploy, choose Properties, and make sure that the Enabled box is cleared (blank).
segment.target: In this case, right-click each application you want to deploy, choose Properties, and make sure that the Enabled box is cleared (blank).

segment.source: Only the applications with the Enabled box selected will stream to client computers.
segment.target: Only the applications with the Enabled box selected will stream to client computers.

segment.source: After you resequence a package and produce a new SFT file for streaming, you can upgrade the old package quickly and easily through the Application Virtualization Server Management Console.
segment.target: After you resequence a package and produce a new SFT file for streaming, you can upgrade the old package quickly and easily through the Application Virtualization Server Management Console.

segment.source: The only operational scenario that requires you to use the Packages node is when you introduce a new version (SFT file) for the package.
segment.target: The only operational scenario that requires you to use the Packages node is when you introduce a new version (SFT file) for the package.

segment.source: Whenever you import applications, assign access and licenses to applications, and so on, the Application Virtualization System tracks this information at the package level.
segment.target: Whenever you import applications, assign access and licenses to applications, and so on, the Application Virtualization System tracks this information at the package level.

segment.source: This means that when you authorize a user to use an application, you are giving the user permission to run any application in the same package.
segment.target: This means that when you authorize a user to use an application, you are giving the user permission to run any application in the same package.

segment.source: Package Version
segment.target: Package Version

segment.source: A package version is represented by a specific SFT file.
segment.target: A package version is represented by a specific SFT file.

segment.source: When you upgrade a package (apply an update to an application or add an application to a package), you generate a new SFT file.
segment.target: When you upgrade a package (apply an update to an application or add an application to a package), you generate a new SFT file.

segment.source: Each time you create a new SFT file, you are creating a new package version.
segment.target: Each time you create a new SFT file, you are creating a new package version.

segment.source: When you import applications through the Application Virtualization Server Management Console, the software automatically creates a package and a package version if they do not already exist.
segment.target: When you import applications through the Application Virtualization Server Management Console, the software automatically creates a package and a package version if they do not already exist.
